case_vignette: A 17-year-old boy comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of pain in his left wrist. That morning the pain increased and he started to have chills and malaise. Last week he had self-resolving left knee pain. He is otherwise healthy and has not had any trauma to the wrist. He recently returned from a camping trip to Minnesota. He is sexually active with one female partner, who uses a diaphragm for contraception. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F). Examination shows several painless violaceous vesiculopustular lesions on the dorsum of both wrists and hands; two lesions are present on the left palm. There is swelling and erythema of the left wrist with severe tenderness to palpation and passive movement.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

Thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms and medical history, I would like to consider a few possible causes for your fever, chills, and purple blister-like spots on your wrists.

One possible cause could be a viral infection such as hand, foot, and mouth disease. This is a common illness that affects children and adults, and it can cause fever, chills, and blisters on the hands and feet.

Another possible cause could be a bacterial infection such as cellulitis. This is a bacterial infection that can cause swelling, redness, and warmth in the affected area. It can also cause fever, chills, and fatigue.

It's also possible that your symptoms could be related to an autoimmune disorder such as lupus or rheumatoid arthritis. These conditions can cause inflammation and joint pain, as well as other symptoms such as fever and fatigue.

I would recommend that you schedule an appointment with a healthcare provider to further evaluate your symptoms and determine the cause

In the meantime, you can try applying a warm compress to your wrist to help reduce the swelling and ease the pain. You can also take over-the-counter pain medication, such as ibuprofen or acetaminophen, to help manage your discomfort.

Please seek medical attention right away if your symptoms worsen or if you experience any other concerning symptoms.

trial_4.summarized_conversation: A patient presents to the clinic with severe pain, swelling, and redness in the left wrist. The patient also reports feeling chills and overall unwell. There is no history of recent activities or injuries that could explain the wrist pain. Additionally, the patient had sudden pain in the left knee last week, but it resolved on its own and has not occurred in any other part of the body. The patient denies any history of surgeries, injuries, or regular medication use. There is no trauma to the wrist, and the symptoms are not related to electronic device use or physical activities. The patient denies performing any repetitive tasks that could be causing the wrist pain and does not experience discomfort specifically during activities. There have been no recent changes in weight or new medical conditions, but the patient has been experiencing chills and malaise.
